questions.question: Which of the following courts has the authority to commute a death sentence?

options.D: Session court and additional session court

questions.explanation: appeals against death sentences imposed by lower courts. During the appeal process, a high court can confirm, reverse, or modify the sentence based on the merits of the case under article 226 and 227. If a high court finds that the death sentence was unjustly imposed, it has the power to commute the sentence to life imprisonment or another lesser sentence. Courts of Law Level Court/Judge Maximum Imprisonment Maximum Fine 1 (Highest) Supreme Court Any period, including death sentence Any amount 2 High Court Any period, including death sentence Any amount 3 District and Sessions Court (Option D) Any period, including death sentence (needs confirmation by High Court) Any amount 4 Assistant Sessions Judge (Option A and B) Up to 10 years Any amount 5 Chief Judicial/Chief Metropolitan Magistrate Up to 7 years Any amount 6 First Class Judicial/Metropolitan Magistrate Up to 3 years Up to I 10,000 7 (Lowest) Second Class Judicial Magistrate Up to 1 year Up to I 5,000

questions.question: Which of the following is punishable under the MTP Act?

options.D: Non-entry in MTP-register, not sending report to DDHS

questions.explanation: maintain proper records or report abortions to the appropriate authorities can lead to legal consequences. Specifically, non-entry in the MTP register and failure to send a report to the District Deputy Health and Family Welfare Officer (DDHS) are considered punishable offenses under the MTP Act. Incorrect Options: MTP done up to 24 weeks (Option A) The Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act allows for abortions to be performed up to 24 weeks of gestation under certain conditions, such as when there is a risk to the life or physical or mental health of the woman, or if there is a substantial risk that the child would be born with physical or mental abnormalities. Done by government-authorized center (Option B) The MTP Act permits abortions to be performed by registered medical practitioners (RMPs) in government-approved facilities, as well as by private practitioners in registered private clinics. Done by experienced RMP (Option C) Under the MTP Act, abortions can be performed by registered medical practitioners (RMPs) who have undergone training and certification in the provision of abortion services Reference: https://dhsfw.assam.gov.in/sites/default/files/swf_utility_folder/departments/dirfw_lipl_in_oid_5/do_u_w ant_2_know/Medical%20Termination%20of%20Pregnancy%20Act%2C%201971_0.pdf

questions.question: A doctor was summoned as a public witness to appear and record his evidence in court. What is correct about this witness?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Expert witness An expert witness is someone who possesses specialized knowledge, skills, or expertise in a particular field that is relevant to the case. In the given scenario, a doctor is summoned as a witness. If the doctor's testimony is related to their medical expertise and is meant to provide insight and explanation to the court on medical matters, then they would be considered an expert witness. Oral evidence (Option A): Oral evidence refers to the testimony or statements provided by witnesses verbally in court. Common witness (Option B): The scenario doesn't provide enough information to suggest that the doctor in question is a common witness. Hostile witness (Option D): A hostile witness is a term used to describe a witness who is uncooperative or openly antagonistic towards the party that called them to testify. Reference: Expert witness

questions.question: Death registration in India done within?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 21 days Explanation: According to the Births and Deaths Registration Act in India, any birth or death occurring in a hospital, medical institution, or at home must be reported to the concerned authorities within 21 days . Birth and Death Registration in India Government/Private Hospitals/Nursing Homes/Medical Institutions : The head of the institution must report births and deaths to the concerned Registrar within 21 days . Homes : The head of the family or any family member must report births and deaths to the Sub Registrar within 21 days . Incorrect Options: 28 days, 30 days, & 40 days (Options B, C, & D): This is not the correct time frame. Registration must happen within 21 days for compliance with the law. Reference: Directorate of Economics & Statistics and Office of Chief Registrar (Births & Deaths)

questions.question: What is the responsibility of the doctor in recording the dying declaration of a victim affected by a fire?

options.B: To record the statement even in the presence of magistrate
options.D: Put the person under oath before declaration

questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - To assess compos mentis A doctor’s responsibility when recording a dying declaration is primarily to assess the mental fitness (compos mentis) of the victim. This ensures that the person is conscious and mentally fit to make a statement about the cause of their death, which is a crucial criterion for the validity of the dying declaration under Section 32 of the Indian Evidence Act (IEA) Dying Declaration (Sec. 32 IEA): A statement by a dying person about the cause or circumstances of their death due to an unlawful act. Legal Basis: Sec. 32 IEA allows dying declarations as evidence; corroboration strengthens its acceptance (Sec. 157 IEA). Flexibility: No specific form, format, or procedure prescribed by law. Who Can Record: Ideally a Magistrate, but in urgent situations, a doctor, police officer, or any witness may record it. Evidential value is highest when recorded by a Magistrate. Key Features and Procedure: Mental State: The person must be conscious and mentally fit (compos mentis). Certified by a doctor if possible, but not mandatory for admissibility. No Oath or Leading Questions: No oath is administered as the dying person is presumed truthful. Avoid leading questions. Narrative Recording: Statement should be recorded in simple narrative form without alterations. Interruptions (e.g., unconsciousness) should be noted, and partial declarations signed by the recorder. Witnesses: Presence of two witnesses strengthens credibility if the Magistrate is unavailable. Submission: Sent to the Magistrate in a sealed cover. Survival of Declarant: If the declarant survives, the statement holds corroborative value but cannot replace oral testimony. Doctor’s Duties: Certify Mental Fitness: Assess and document the declarant's ability to make a statement. Certification is preferred but not mandatory for the declaration's validity. Record Accurately: Write the statement verbatim in a simple narrative style. Note any interruptions (e.g., loss of consciousness). Act Promptly: Record the declaration without delay if death seems imminent. Presence of Witnesses: Ensure two witnesses are present if possible. Submission: Forward the declaration to the Magistrate in a sealed cover. Expert Opinion: Be cautious when commenting on a patient's ability to speak or act after a fatal injury. To record the statement even in the presence of a magistrate (Option B): Ideally, a Magistrate should record the dying declaration for it to carry the most weight. However, if the Magistrate is unavailable, a doctor can record the statement, but there is no legal requirement to do so in the Magistrate's presence. Cross-examine the person (Option C): Cross-examining the person is not part of the process of recording a dying declaration. The purpose is to record their statement, not to question them as a part of a legal cross-examination. Put the person under oath before declaration (Option D): The dying declaration does not require an oath to be administered because the person is presumed to be truthful when making a statement under the belief of impending death. The law does not mandate an oath or formal swearing before a dying declaration. Reference: Gautam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 3rd Edition Page 48, 49, 50

questions.question: What is the appropriate course of action following the observation of cigarette burn marks on the forearm of a 14-year-old girl who presents to a doctor with a fractured forearm, claiming to have fallen and hit her hand?

options.B: To do a complete physical examination
options.C: To tell or discuss with colleagues that she is a case of abuse
options.D: To call local social worker for help

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) To do a complete physical examination Explanation: The discovery of cigarette burns suggests the possibility of abuse. A complete physical examination is essential to assess all injuries and document any signs of abuse. This is the first step in ensuring the child's safety and gathering evidence for further investigation. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 431-433

questions.question: Which organization is related to the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Child and welfare committees Explanation: Under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act , Child and Welfare Committees play a key role in addressing and responding to cases of child sexual abuse. They are responsible for ensuring the safety and protection of children and ensuring that appropriate actions are taken when cases of abuse are reported. The committees work with various authorities to ensure the welfare of the child victim and provide necessary support services. Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act Enacted in 2012, it is law in India designed to protect children under the age of 18 from sexual abuse, sexual harassment, and pornography. Key Features of the POCSO Act: Gender-neutral law It covers penetrative and non-penetrative assault, sexual harassment, and use of children for pornography Burden of proof is on the accused, unlike many other criminal laws where the burden is on the prosecution Mandatory reporting by adults and failure to do so can be punishable Special courts for the trial of offenses to ensure a child-friendly environment Identity of the victim is to be protected, and the proceedings are to be conducted in camera to prevent exposure Recent Changes and Developments in the POCSO Act: 2019 Amendment Stricter Punishments: Death penalty for aggravated sexual assault against children The minimum punishment for penetrative sexual assault increased to 10 years, and for aggravated penetrative sexual assault increased to 20 years, with the possibility of life imprisonment or death in extreme cases. Fast-track Courts to ensure swift disposal of POCSO cases, given the backlog of pending cases. Clarifications on ‘Touch’ and Sexual Intent: The intent behind physical contact is crucial in determining whether it qualifies as an offense under POCSO. Digital Crimes Against Children: Provisions related to the use of children for pornographic and online exploitation purposes have been emphasized with stricter penalties. Incorrect Options: Women and child safety department (Option B) : While this department focuses on general safety measures, it does not directly implement the POCSO Act . Children rights protection committee (Option C) : This committee works on children's rights but is not specifically responsible for the enforcement of the POCSO Act . All of the above (Option D) : Not all these organizations are directly linked to the POCSO Act , so this option is incorrect. Reference: The Protection of Children From Sexual Offences (Amendment) Act 2019

questions.question: If a healthcare professional is found guilty of professional misconduct, they must provide the patient's records promptly upon request, within:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 72 hours Explanation: If a healthcare professional is found guilty of professional misconduct, they are required to provide the patient’s records within 72 hours upon request. This timeframe is mandated to ensure that patients have timely access to their medical information when needed. If a healthcare professional fails to maintain medical records of indoor patients for 3 years and refuses to provide them within 72 hours upon the patient's request, it constitutes a violation of professional conduct and legal requirements. 48 hours (Option B), 24 hours (Option C), & 7 days (Option D) are all incorrect options. A 72-hour period is the correct legal limit for healthcare professionals to submit the records following misconduct allegations. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 12

questions.question: A surgeon performs a hysterectomy for uterine fibroids after obtaining relevant informed consent from the patient. Despite adequate precautions, the ureter was injured intraoperatively. Under which of the following principles will the doctor not be held responsible for this act?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Medical Maloccurrence Explanation: This incident represents a medical maloccurrence because the complication arose from an unavoidable risk associated with the surgery, despite the surgeon providing quality care and obtaining informed consent. Medical Maloccurrence A less than ideal medical outcome not linked to the quality of care. Types: Anticipated medical/surgical complications (unavoidable risks). Unpredictable complications (unavoidable). Complications from informed patient-doctor decisions that seem inappropriate in hindsight. Characteristics: Often unrelated to the quality of care. May occur despite good medical attention (e.g., idiosyncratic drug responses, nerve damage during surgery). Incorrect Options: Novus Actus Interveniens (Unrelated Intervening Action) (Option A): This refers to an event that breaks the chain of causation from the original negligent act. Negligence Element : Requires proof of negligence to establish a break in causation. Often applied in incidents like leaving surgical instruments inside a patient. Pleas are rarely accepted by courts. It is not applicable here, as there is no intervening act causing the injury. Doctrine of Res Ipsa Loquitur ( Option C ): Means "the thing speaks for itself"; Used when negligence is obvious. Expert Evidence : Patients don’t need to prove negligence through expert testimony; the burden shifts to the doctor to prove innocence. Conditions : Injury would not have occurred without negligence. The doctor had exclusive control over the treatment or instrument causing injury. The patient was not contributory to negligence. Examples : Blood transfusion errors (infected blood, mismatches). Failure to administer necessary vaccines. Overprescribing medication. Wrong-site surgeries. Leaving surgical instruments inside the patient. Failing to remove swabs, leading to complications. Prolonged splinting causing loss of use of a limb. However, in this case, ureteral injury is a known risk of hysterectomy, so it does not inherently indicate negligence. Physician error (Option D): Physician error refers to a deviation from the standard of care. If the injury resulted from a genuine error or lack of skill, the doctor could be held responsible under this principle. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 19, 20, 21

questions.question: What is the penalty for causing the death of a patient due to the use of counterfeit medication/spurious drug?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Life imprisonment Explanation: Under the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940 (Section 27A and 27B), if a patient dies due to the use of counterfeit/spurious drugs, the penalty includes life imprisonment and a fine of at least I 10 lakhs or three times the value of the confiscated drugs, whichever is higher. Counterfeit drugs: Illegal. Given to cheat or harm a person. These drugs do not have the same therapeutic effect as genuine drugs and may lead to treatment failure. Counterfeit drugs are not subjected to proper quality control. People making illegal drugs are punished or jailed. Types Description Example Spurious Drugs Have no active ingredient 500 mg paracetamol tablet → when checked, it contains no paracetamol in it. Made by illegal people other than the manufacturer to copy the drug. Misbranded Drugs Low-quality drugs 500 mg tablet → when checked, it contains only 200 mg. Made by the same manufacturer to increase profit. Adulterated Drugs Addition of harmful or unwanted excipients Cough syrup made in India containing ethylene glycol → when checked, GMP guidelines do not approve these substances. Ethylene glycol is harmful and not approved as an excipient by GMP. Reference: Goodman and Gilman 14th Ed Page145. Tackling Counterfeit Drugs: The Challenges and Possibilities - PMC https://www.indiacode.nic.in/bitstream/123456789/15278/1/drug_cosmeticsa1940-23.pdf

questions.question: In relation to the punishment of perjury, which specific section of the IPC addresses this matter?
questions.explanation: with the punishment for giving false evidence (perjury) in any stage of a judicial proceeding or fabricating false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of a judicial proceeding. BNS related to false evidence/false certificate/disappearance of evidence: BNS 227/ Section 191 (Option A) Giving false evidence/statement under oath by a witness (Perjury) BNS 228/ Section 192 (Option B) Fabrication of evidence BNS 229/ IPC 193 (Option C) Punishment for providing false evidence under oath (Punishment for perjury) (imprisonment of upto 7 years + fine) BNS 234/ Section 197 (Option D) Punishment for issuing a false certificate (imprisonment of upto 7 years + fine) BNS 238 Punishment for disappearance of vital evidence (imprisonment of upto 7 years + fine) BNS 239 Intentional omission of vital information by person legally bound to inform Reference: Gautam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology pages- 48,51,471

questions.question: In a civil negligence case against a doctor, who is responsible for providing evidence?

options.B: Police not under the rank of sub-inspector

questions.explanation: proof lies with the patient. The patient is the one making the claim against the doctor and alleging negligence. Therefore, it is the patient's responsibility to provide evidence and prove that the doctor's actions or omissions fell below the standard of care expected, resulting in harm or injury. · Feature Civil Negligence Criminal Negligence Offense No specific and clear violation of law Must have specifically violated a particular criminal law Negligence Simple absence of care and skill Gross negligence, inattention, or lack of competence Conduct of physician Compared to a generally accepted simple standard of conduct Not compared to a single test Consent for act Good defense, cannot recover damages Not a defense, can be prosecuted Trial by Civil court Criminal court Evidence Strong evidence is sufficient Guilt must be proved beyond reasonable doubt Punishment Liable to pay damages Imprisonment, fine, or both Contributory negligence Defense for doctor Not a defense Double jeopardy Cannot be tried twice for the same offense Can be tried twice for the same crime Damage Repairable damage or harm to patient Irreparable damage to the patient Dispute Between two parties in their individual capacities Between the State and the offending doctor Complainant Sufferer party is the complainant Public prosecutor on behalf of the State is the complainant Police not under the rank of sub-inspector (Option B) The police are not directly involved in civil negligence cases against doctors. Magistrate (Option C) In civil negligence cases against doctors, the burden of proof does not lie with the magistrate. Their role is to oversee the proceedings and apply the relevant laws. Doctor (Option D) is the defendant in a civil negligence case, meaning they are the party being accused of negligence. It is not the doctor's burden to prove their innocence Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page. 15-16. The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, K S Narayan Reddy, OP Murty, 35th Edition, Page. 29-32.
